Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <CHMEX> yes .. ( I know little about this and my math is not at that level )

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @CHMEX you are right, there is no address data leaking, but there are other unique numbers which metadata analysts can use to figure things out

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <CHMEX> ok

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> I highly highly suggest to everyone that they encrypt things inside the encrypted memo field

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Just assume one day, sha256 and zaddrs will be completely broken

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> don't put  very important data in there, without "double bagging it"

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> if you are just sending "Hey i like your blog", then it's not as important, like in chat applications. But for files, they should be encrypted before ever hitting a memo field

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Some wills might have some public and private data, for instance, a will might have sensitive bank account routing numbers/etc. With HushList, it's possible to make part of your will public, and refer cryptographically to the other part of your will, which is hidden

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> such as "the hash deadbeef represents the sha256 of the hidden part of my will", and you store that in the public will

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> and then you can make it public one day, and people can verify it's the will you referred to publicly

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> I plan to have encryption features built into our wallets, so users will be able to encrypt their memos another time, as easily as we can make it

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <ITM> Let say if I have application Chat A, Application Chat B and Application Group Chat C. 

All connected to Hush blockchain. Now All application are real time. If I send 10000 messages at 0.1 hush total from Chat A. I don't really care if the transaction get confirm or not since Chat B will analyse the mem transaction to insert a message in his node and reply back yes I got it. Chat A use mem pool and will not rebroadcast it. If no response, Chat A will resend the message (with the correct fees) and only then get it accepted. 

How is this type of attack dealt with?

Secondly what stop participants of just cloning hush and creating there own P2P network? Since maybe there find hush price too much and will create a clone with 10x cheaper fees?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <ITM> So essential bad actor will only use mem cache transaction and piggy off 10000 nodes for security.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @ITM HushList is a protocol, and any sapling-enabled coin can implement. So if people "clone" Hush or HushList, then we have won, because they are adopting our tech. HushList protocol is like HTTP versus a single website. It's much larger than one blockchain or coin or network. To fully realize it's potential, thousands of networks will have HushList protocol and some will be private + temporary, coming in and out of existence, while others will be public and longer lasting.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> In that seething chaos, HUSH+ARRR are (arrr) at the forefront of shielded transaction adoption. I don't see a lot of Zcash protocol coins actually focused on using their shielded addresses, outside of HUSH+ARRR

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @ITM your mempool tricks could be seen as a bug or feature

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @ITM and radix42 mentioned those tricks to me, that they were probably possible, about 2 years ago. We considered them  a feature back then

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> because it allows you to avoid having to wait 2.5 minutes for a confirmation

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @ITM i really like that you are thinking of attack scenarios

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @ITM in my original hushlist paper, I described it as a `HushList Protocol: Censorship Resistant Metadata-Minimizing Multi-Blockchain Communication`

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> `Multi-Blockchain` is very important, it's not just lip service

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> If I was a nation state, and I knew that only one blockchain has certain data, then I can block 1 P2P port and that prevents many people from accessing that blockchain in that country

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> But if the application can send your data to a random assortment of 1000 blockchains, or however many you want, blocking P2P ports of individual coins is no longer viable. each blockchain is an independent backup of your data

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> and different coins are likely to have different node operators, so your data gets spread in different ways geographically, when you spread it across a few chains

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> censorship concerns are more important for public data

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> for private data, you don't really need to worry about all that stuff
